Research Project

Research Project

Research Methods 2026-27

Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
The Research Project module is taken by all students studying a Life Sciences degree. This 30-credit module runs throughout the Level 6 year and gives students the opportunity to experience authentic Life Sciences research, applying the knowledge and skills that they have developed through the first two years, supported by the Research Methods module in Semester 1 of Level 6 and under the guidance of an individual named supervisor. Students may work as a group to develop related or collaborative projects, although the assessment is always individual.

A large diversity of projects is available to students, including but not limited to lab-based (in research labs), field research, bioinformatics, mathematical modelling, computer analysis, meta-analysis, systematic review, education research, outreach, school-based projects. Students express a preference for keywords describing project content and style of project, and projects are allocated to optimise the fit between student preference and available projects.

Students meet their supervisor at the start of Semester 1 and develop a proposal for their project, including a literature review, aims and proposed methodology, with regular meetings with and guidance from their supervisor throughout the semester. Students are also instructed in relevant aspects of safety. The proposal is submitted at the end of Semester 1. This process is supported by the concurrent Research Methods module, in which students will develop their skills in critical analysis of literature and appreciation of research ethics and will choose to study relevant research methodologies and associated analytical methods form a menu of options.

The substantive experimental work for the project is carried out in the first half of Semester 2, followed by the writing of the final project report, which is the primary assessed output of the project. Students also produce another specialist communication of their project work, as a flexible assessment, which might involve a live presentation, video, poster, or a focussed written report for a defined audience.

The student’s approach and development of skills throughout the project will also be assessed by their supervisor at the end of the project period.

Successful completion of the Research project module will equip students with the organisational, technical and communication skills to carry out individual project work in their future careers.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide students with an insight into the process of scientific research and debate;

2. Develop students’ confidence to work independently and with others, to effectively and efficiently attain a research aim;

3. Develop students’ ability to communicate scientific concepts and findings in a variety of formats.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Research Project module is taken by all students studying a Life Sciences degree. This 30-credit module runs throughout the Level 6 year and gives students the opportunity to experience authentic Life Sciences research, applying the knowledge and skills that they have developed through the first two years, supported by the Research Methods module in Semester 1 of Year 3 and under the guidance of an individual named supervisor. Students may work as a group to develop related or collaborative projects, although the assessment is always individual.

A large diversity of projects is available to students, including but not limited to lab-based (in research labs), field research, bioinformatics, mathematical modelling, computer analysis, meta-analysis, systematic review, education research, outreach, school-based projects. Students express a preference for keywords describing project content and style of project, and projects are allocated to optimise the fit between student preference and available projects.

Students meet their supervisor at the start of Semester 1 and develop a proposal for their project, including a literature review, aims and proposed methodology, with regular meetings with and guidance from their supervisor throughout the semester. Students are also instructed in relevant aspects of safety. The proposal is submitted at the end of Semester 1. This process is supported by the concurrent Research Methods module, in which students will develop their skills in critical analysis of literature and appreciation of research ethics and will choose to study relevant research methodologies and associated analytical methods form a menu of options.

The substantive experimental work for the project is carried out in the first half of Semester 2, followed by the writing of the final project report, which is the primary assessed output of the project. Students also produce another specialist communication of their project work, as a flexible assessment, which might involve a live presentation, video, poster, or a focussed written report for a defined audience. The student’s approach and development of skills throughout the project will also be assessed by their supervisor at the end of the project period.

Successful completion of the Research project module will equip students with the organisational, technical and communication skills to carry out individual project work in their future careers.
Outline Syllabus
Students will indicate preferences from lists of project keywords in relevant, cognate areas. The exact nature and format of the project and the timing of its elements may vary, but all projects are designed to meet the same set of learning outcomes, including research planning, background reading, conducting research, analysing findings, communicating findings orally and in writing.

Students will receive specific instruction about the organisational aspects of their project work, as well as about preparation for the assessments (report writing, talk preparation etc.).
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The setup of the teaching on this module deliberately mimics the authentic style of supervisor-researcher interaction. The student will be supported by their supervisor and potentially other research staff and collaborators to develop active, independent learning in a research-connected framework. The interaction will involve a baseline expectation of one meeting of up to one hour every 2 weeks but may be much more frequent depending on the style of the project. The meetings will involve the student explaining progress followed by discussion, building planning, time management, problem solving, critical thinking and collaborative working skills.

This collaborative teaching method will be supported by lecture and workshop-based introduction to the module, and training in report writing and presentations.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed using a series of outputs authentically designed around the operation of actual research projects, and thus reflect real-life and career-based based scenarios.

The students will research the background to their project area and review the literature, then develop the aims and planned approach to the work with the guidance of their supervisor, all to be submitted in the ‘project proposal’ at the end of Semester 1. This assessment will assess research skills, planning and critical thinking. At the end of semester 2, the students will report the findings of their project in the ‘final report’, in the style of a research paper, to include abstract, lay summary, introduction, methods, results and discussion. The report will require students to demonstrate analytical and technical communication skills. Supervisors will advise on the planning of the documents and will read and give formative feedback on a draft proposal and final report.

Students will also communicate the findings of their project in another technical style, in a flexible assessment with the option of a presentation, poster, video presentation, or other formal report to a defined audience. A common feature of this assessment will be the requirement for students to be assessed on a verbal discussion of the project with assessors. This choice of assessment (flexible assessment) is provided to increase inclusivity according to the principles of Universal Design for Learning. This allows students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes using the best method for them. To ensure equity between the methods the marking rubric will be identical apart from the criteria related specifically to the presentation method chosen: students will be expected to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes whichever form of assessment they choose (Inclusivity. Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Supervisors will also assess the students on their performance during the project, including their informal communication, technical abilities, record keeping, time management, and commitment, in the ‘Approach and Technique’ assessment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To plan and execute a piece of scientific research, in a responsible, safe and ethical manner.
 LO2 To analyse and critically evaluate data, information, literature and/or observations, and draw valid conclusions.
 LO3 To appropriately communicate findings, in a variety of formats (oral, written reports) to supervisor, research staff and peers.
 LO4 To maintain a clear and accurate record of work and progress.
 LO5 To evaluate and report upon relevant scientific literature.
 LO6 To evaluate own performance and working standards by reflection, and place work in a wider scientific context.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Information technology
 S2 Information retrieval and review
 S3 Time management and organisational skills
 S4 Problem solving and reasoning skills
 S5 Ethical awareness
 S6 Communication
 S7 Critical thinking and problem solving - Critical analysis
 S8 Comprehend and use data effectively
 S9 Evidence based reasoning
 S10 Independent-learning

Research Project 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:30
Module Code:BIOS301
Deliveries:Liverpool campus · Whole Session
Online · Whole Session
 
In Programmes:Pharmacology BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Master of Biological Sciences MBiol 2024-25
Microbiology and Infection BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Bioveterinary Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Anatomy & Human Biology BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biomedical Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biochemistry BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Zoology BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biological Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Research Project
Short Title
Research Project
Module Code
BIOS301
Academic Year
2026-27
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Online
Delivery Periods
Whole Session
Credits
30
Level
Level 6
Module Coordinator
Andrew Bates
Assigned To
Matthew Wharton
Andrew Bates
Life and Human Sciences Admin
Marketing
Quality Team
Status
 
Development
Date of Approval
14 Sep 2023, 15:08
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
450
Co-requisites
Research Methods 2026-27
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
The Research Project module is taken by all students studying a Life Sciences degree. This 30-credit module runs throughout the Level 6 year and gives students the opportunity to experience authentic Life Sciences research, applying the knowledge and skills that they have developed through the first two years, supported by the Research Methods module in Semester 1 of Level 6 and under the guidance of an individual named supervisor. Students may work as a group to develop related or collaborative projects, although the assessment is always individual.

A large diversity of projects is available to students, including but not limited to lab-based (in research labs), field research, bioinformatics, mathematical modelling, computer analysis, meta-analysis, systematic review, education research, outreach, school-based projects. Students express a preference for keywords describing project content and style of project, and projects are allocated to optimise the fit between student preference and available projects.

Students meet their supervisor at the start of Semester 1 and develop a proposal for their project, including a literature review, aims and proposed methodology, with regular meetings with and guidance from their supervisor throughout the semester. Students are also instructed in relevant aspects of safety. The proposal is submitted at the end of Semester 1. This process is supported by the concurrent Research Methods module, in which students will develop their skills in critical analysis of literature and appreciation of research ethics and will choose to study relevant research methodologies and associated analytical methods form a menu of options.

The substantive experimental work for the project is carried out in the first half of Semester 2, followed by the writing of the final project report, which is the primary assessed output of the project. Students also produce another specialist communication of their project work, as a flexible assessment, which might involve a live presentation, video, poster, or a focussed written report for a defined audience.

The student’s approach and development of skills throughout the project will also be assessed by their supervisor at the end of the project period.

Successful completion of the Research project module will equip students with the organisational, technical and communication skills to carry out individual project work in their future careers.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide students with an insight into the process of scientific research and debate;

2. Develop students’ confidence to work independently and with others, to effectively and efficiently attain a research aim;

3. Develop students’ ability to communicate scientific concepts and findings in a variety of formats.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Research Project module is taken by all students studying a Life Sciences degree. This 30-credit module runs throughout the Level 6 year and gives students the opportunity to experience authentic Life Sciences research, applying the knowledge and skills that they have developed through the first two years, supported by the Research Methods module in Semester 1 of Year 3 and under the guidance of an individual named supervisor. Students may work as a group to develop related or collaborative projects, although the assessment is always individual.

A large diversity of projects is available to students, including but not limited to lab-based (in research labs), field research, bioinformatics, mathematical modelling, computer analysis, meta-analysis, systematic review, education research, outreach, school-based projects. Students express a preference for keywords describing project content and style of project, and projects are allocated to optimise the fit between student preference and available projects.

Students meet their supervisor at the start of Semester 1 and develop a proposal for their project, including a literature review, aims and proposed methodology, with regular meetings with and guidance from their supervisor throughout the semester. Students are also instructed in relevant aspects of safety. The proposal is submitted at the end of Semester 1. This process is supported by the concurrent Research Methods module, in which students will develop their skills in critical analysis of literature and appreciation of research ethics and will choose to study relevant research methodologies and associated analytical methods form a menu of options.

The substantive experimental work for the project is carried out in the first half of Semester 2, followed by the writing of the final project report, which is the primary assessed output of the project. Students also produce another specialist communication of their project work, as a flexible assessment, which might involve a live presentation, video, poster, or a focussed written report for a defined audience. The student’s approach and development of skills throughout the project will also be assessed by their supervisor at the end of the project period.

Successful completion of the Research project module will equip students with the organisational, technical and communication skills to carry out individual project work in their future careers.
Outline Syllabus
Students will indicate preferences from lists of project keywords in relevant, cognate areas. The exact nature and format of the project and the timing of its elements may vary, but all projects are designed to meet the same set of learning outcomes, including research planning, background reading, conducting research, analysing findings, communicating findings orally and in writing.

Students will receive specific instruction about the organisational aspects of their project work, as well as about preparation for the assessments (report writing, talk preparation etc.).
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The setup of the teaching on this module deliberately mimics the authentic style of supervisor-researcher interaction. The student will be supported by their supervisor and potentially other research staff and collaborators to develop active, independent learning in a research-connected framework. The interaction will involve a baseline expectation of one meeting of up to one hour every 2 weeks but may be much more frequent depending on the style of the project. The meetings will involve the student explaining progress followed by discussion, building planning, time management, problem solving, critical thinking and collaborative working skills.

This collaborative teaching method will be supported by lecture and workshop-based introduction to the module, and training in report writing and presentations.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed using a series of outputs authentically designed around the operation of actual research projects, and thus reflect real-life and career-based based scenarios.

The students will research the background to their project area and review the literature, then develop the aims and planned approach to the work with the guidance of their supervisor, all to be submitted in the ‘project proposal’ at the end of Semester 1. This assessment will assess research skills, planning and critical thinking. At the end of semester 2, the students will report the findings of their project in the ‘final report’, in the style of a research paper, to include abstract, lay summary, introduction, methods, results and discussion. The report will require students to demonstrate analytical and technical communication skills. Supervisors will advise on the planning of the documents and will read and give formative feedback on a draft proposal and final report.

Students will also communicate the findings of their project in another technical style, in a flexible assessment with the option of a presentation, poster, video presentation, or other formal report to a defined audience. A common feature of this assessment will be the requirement for students to be assessed on a verbal discussion of the project with assessors. This choice of assessment (flexible assessment) is provided to increase inclusivity according to the principles of Universal Design for Learning. This allows students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes using the best method for them. To ensure equity between the methods the marking rubric will be identical apart from the criteria related specifically to the presentation method chosen: students will be expected to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes whichever form of assessment they choose (Inclusivity. Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Supervisors will also assess the students on their performance during the project, including their informal communication, technical abilities, record keeping, time management, and commitment, in the ‘Approach and Technique’ assessment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin

Blurb
Overview
The Research Project module is taken by all students studying a Life Sciences degree. This 30-credit module runs throughout the Level 6 year and gives students the opportunity to experience authentic Life Sciences research, applying the knowledge and skills that they have developed through the first two years, supported by the Research Methods module in Semester 1 of Level 6 and under the guidance of an individual named supervisor. Students may work as a group to develop related or collaborative projects, although the assessment is always individual.

A large diversity of projects is available to students, including but not limited to lab-based (in research labs), field research, bioinformatics, mathematical modelling, computer analysis, meta-analysis, systematic review, education research, outreach, school-based projects. Students express a preference for keywords describing project content and style of project, and projects are allocated to optimise the fit between student preference and available projects.

Students meet their supervisor at the start of Semester 1 and develop a proposal for their project, including a literature review, aims and proposed methodology, with regular meetings with and guidance from their supervisor throughout the semester. Students are also instructed in relevant aspects of safety. The proposal is submitted at the end of Semester 1. This process is supported by the concurrent Research Methods module, in which students will develop their skills in critical analysis of literature and appreciation of research ethics and will choose to study relevant research methodologies and associated analytical methods form a menu of options.

The substantive experimental work for the project is carried out in the first half of Semester 2, followed by the writing of the final project report, which is the primary assessed output of the project. Students also produce another specialist communication of their project work, as a flexible assessment, which might involve a live presentation, video, poster, or a focussed written report for a defined audience.

The student’s approach and development of skills throughout the project will also be assessed by their supervisor at the end of the project period.

Successful completion of the Research project module will equip students with the organisational, technical and communication skills to carry out individual project work in their future careers.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide students with an insight into the process of scientific research and debate;

2. Develop students’ confidence to work independently and with others, to effectively and efficiently attain a research aim;

3. Develop students’ ability to communicate scientific concepts and findings in a variety of formats.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Research Project module is taken by all students studying a Life Sciences degree. This 30-credit module runs throughout the Level 6 year and gives students the opportunity to experience authentic Life Sciences research, applying the knowledge and skills that they have developed through the first two years, supported by the Research Methods module in Semester 1 of Year 3 and under the guidance of an individual named supervisor. Students may work as a group to develop related or collaborative projects, although the assessment is always individual.

A large diversity of projects is available to students, including but not limited to lab-based (in research labs), field research, bioinformatics, mathematical modelling, computer analysis, meta-analysis, systematic review, education research, outreach, school-based projects. Students express a preference for keywords describing project content and style of project, and projects are allocated to optimise the fit between student preference and available projects.

Students meet their supervisor at the start of Semester 1 and develop a proposal for their project, including a literature review, aims and proposed methodology, with regular meetings with and guidance from their supervisor throughout the semester. Students are also instructed in relevant aspects of safety. The proposal is submitted at the end of Semester 1. This process is supported by the concurrent Research Methods module, in which students will develop their skills in critical analysis of literature and appreciation of research ethics and will choose to study relevant research methodologies and associated analytical methods form a menu of options.

The substantive experimental work for the project is carried out in the first half of Semester 2, followed by the writing of the final project report, which is the primary assessed output of the project. Students also produce another specialist communication of their project work, as a flexible assessment, which might involve a live presentation, video, poster, or a focussed written report for a defined audience. The student’s approach and development of skills throughout the project will also be assessed by their supervisor at the end of the project period.

Successful completion of the Research project module will equip students with the organisational, technical and communication skills to carry out individual project work in their future careers.
Outline Syllabus
Students will indicate preferences from lists of project keywords in relevant, cognate areas. The exact nature and format of the project and the timing of its elements may vary, but all projects are designed to meet the same set of learning outcomes, including research planning, background reading, conducting research, analysing findings, communicating findings orally and in writing.

Students will receive specific instruction about the organisational aspects of their project work, as well as about preparation for the assessments (report writing, talk preparation etc.).
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The setup of the teaching on this module deliberately mimics the authentic style of supervisor-researcher interaction. The student will be supported by their supervisor and potentially other research staff and collaborators to develop active, independent learning in a research-connected framework. The interaction will involve a baseline expectation of one meeting of up to one hour every 2 weeks but may be much more frequent depending on the style of the project. The meetings will involve the student explaining progress followed by discussion, building planning, time management, problem solving, critical thinking and collaborative working skills.

This collaborative teaching method will be supported by lecture and workshop-based introduction to the module, and training in report writing and presentations.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed using a series of outputs authentically designed around the operation of actual research projects, and thus reflect real-life and career-based based scenarios.

The students will research the background to their project area and review the literature, then develop the aims and planned approach to the work with the guidance of their supervisor, all to be submitted in the ‘project proposal’ at the end of Semester 1. This assessment will assess research skills, planning and critical thinking. At the end of semester 2, the students will report the findings of their project in the ‘final report’, in the style of a research paper, to include abstract, lay summary, introduction, methods, results and discussion. The report will require students to demonstrate analytical and technical communication skills. Supervisors will advise on the planning of the documents and will read and give formative feedback on a draft proposal and final report.

Students will also communicate the findings of their project in another technical style, in a flexible assessment with the option of a presentation, poster, video presentation, or other formal report to a defined audience. A common feature of this assessment will be the requirement for students to be assessed on a verbal discussion of the project with assessors. This choice of assessment (flexible assessment) is provided to increase inclusivity according to the principles of Universal Design for Learning. This allows students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes using the best method for them. To ensure equity between the methods the marking rubric will be identical apart from the criteria related specifically to the presentation method chosen: students will be expected to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes whichever form of assessment they choose (Inclusivity. Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Supervisors will also assess the students on their performance during the project, including their informal communication, technical abilities, record keeping, time management, and commitment, in the ‘Approach and Technique’ assessment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To plan and execute a piece of scientific research, in a responsible, safe and ethical manner.
 LO2 To analyse and critically evaluate data, information, literature and/or observations, and draw valid conclusions.
 LO3 To appropriately communicate findings, in a variety of formats (oral, written reports) to supervisor, research staff and peers.
 LO4 To maintain a clear and accurate record of work and progress.
 LO5 To evaluate and report upon relevant scientific literature.
 LO6 To evaluate own performance and working standards by reflection, and place work in a wider scientific context.
